name: Lovable
description: AI-powered app builder that generates React applications from natural language prompts

limitations.title: Credit System Burns Through Budget
limitations.description: Every prompt, edit, and bug fix consumes credits. Users report spending $500-2,000 on a single project, especially when fixing AI-generated bugs.

limitations.title: Bug-Fixing Loops
limitations.description: The AI often introduces new errors while fixing old ones. Users get stuck in endless debugging cycles that consume credits without progress.

limitations.title: Code Not Production-Ready
limitations.description: Generated code has inflexible data structures and tightly-coupled logic. Simple apps work, but complex business logic breaks easily.

limitations.title: The 70% Problem
limitations.description: Lovable gets you 70% of the way to a working app, but the last 30% requires significant manual work or professional development.

limitations.title: Authentication Issues
limitations.description: Complex auth flows, OAuth integration, and session management frequently fail or require extensive manual fixes.

limitations.title: Deployment Failures
limitations.description: Projects that work in preview often fail in production. Blank screens, missing files, and partial deployments are common.

bestFor: Quick prototypes, MVP validation, simple CRUD apps
notFor: Complex business logic, production apps, enterprise software
productionPath: Export code to GitHub, refactor architecture, add proper error handling, implement security, optimize performance

faqs.question: Why does Lovable keep making the same mistakes?
faqs.answer: Lovable's AI doesn't maintain long-term context. Each prompt is processed somewhat independently, so it may 'forget' previous fixes. This is why you can get stuck in loops where the same bug keeps returning.

faqs.question: Is Lovable good for production apps?
faqs.answer: No. Lovable is designed for prototyping and validation, not production. The generated code lacks proper architecture, security hardening, and scalability considerations needed for real-world deployment.

faqs.question: How much does Lovable actually cost?
faqs.answer: While Lovable offers a free tier, most users report spending $200-500 for simple apps and $1,000-3,000+ for more complex projects due to the credit system charging for every interaction including bug fixes.

faqs.question: Can I hire someone to fix my Lovable project?
faqs.answer: Yes. Many developers specialize in taking Lovable prototypes to production. Expect to pay $5,000-15,000 depending on complexity, as significant refactoring is usually required.

name: Bolt
description: Full-stack AI app builder that generates frontend, backend, and database from prompts

limitations.title: Token Costs Explode Quickly
limitations.description: Users report spending $1,000+ on tokens for single projects. Authentication bugs alone can consume 3-8 million tokens as the AI repeatedly fails to fix them.

limitations.title: Context Degradation at Scale
limitations.description: Projects with 15-20+ components experience severe context loss. The AI forgets patterns, creates duplicates, and loses consistency as projects grow.

limitations.title: Deployment Nightmares
limitations.description: Blank screens, missing files, and partial deployments plague larger projects. One-click deployment works for simple apps but fails for anything complex.

limitations.title: Supabase Auth Disasters
limitations.description: Authentication with Supabase is notoriously problematic. Users report spending millions of tokens and days trying to get basic auth working.

limitations.title: No Local Development
limitations.description: Bolt is cloud-only with no option to run projects locally. This makes debugging, testing, and professional development workflows impossible.

limitations.title: Project Size Limits
limitations.description: Large projects exceed Bolt's context window, triggering 'Project size exceeded' errors. Paid plans help but don't eliminate the fundamental limitation.

bestFor: Quick full-stack prototypes, simple apps with database needs
notFor: Large applications, team projects, production deployments
productionPath: Export code, refactor for modularity, implement proper auth, add error handling, set up CI/CD pipeline

faqs.question: Why did I spend so many tokens on Bolt?
faqs.answer: Bolt charges tokens for every interaction, including failed attempts. Error loops multiply costs exponentially—a simple auth bug that takes 3 attempts can consume 3-5 million tokens.

faqs.question: Why does my Bolt app show a blank screen?
faqs.answer: Blank screens typically indicate deployment failures, missing environment variables, or broken API connections. Bolt's deployment works for simple apps but often fails with complex routing or authentication.

faqs.question: Is Bolt better than Lovable?
faqs.answer: They serve different needs. Bolt generates full-stack apps with backends; Lovable focuses on frontend. Both have similar limitations for production use—neither produces truly production-ready code.

faqs.question: Can I take my Bolt project to production?
faqs.answer: Not directly. Bolt projects need significant refactoring for production: proper error handling, security hardening, performance optimization, and architectural improvements. Budget $5,000-20,000 for professional finishing.

name: v0
description: AI-powered UI component generator that creates React/Next.js components from prompts and images

limitations.title: UI Only - No Backend
limitations.description: v0 only generates frontend components. There's no database, API, or backend logic. You need to build or integrate everything else yourself.

limitations.title: Components Need Integration Work
limitations.description: Generated components are standalone. Connecting them to state management, APIs, and routing requires developer knowledge.

limitations.title: Limited Application Architecture
limitations.description: v0 generates individual components, not complete applications. You still need to architect how everything fits together.

limitations.title: Iteration Limits on Free Tier
limitations.description: The free tier has strict generation limits. Complex UIs requiring multiple iterations quickly exhaust free credits.

bestFor: UI component generation, design-to-code, shadcn/ui projects
notFor: Full applications, backend logic, database-driven apps
productionPath: Copy components into your Next.js project, add state management, connect to backend APIs, implement business logic
commonProblems: No way to add backend logic

faqs.question: Can v0 build a complete app?
faqs.answer: No. v0 only generates UI components. For a complete app, you need to add backend logic, database connections, authentication, and state management separately or use v0 alongside other tools.

faqs.question: Is v0 better than Lovable or Bolt?
faqs.answer: Different tools for different purposes. v0 excels at generating high-quality UI components but has no backend. Lovable and Bolt attempt full applications but with lower UI quality. Many developers use v0 for UI and other tools for logic.

faqs.question: How do I use v0 components in my project?
faqs.answer: v0 generates copy-paste ready code. Copy the component, add it to your project, then connect it to your state management and backend. This requires React development knowledge.

name: Cursor
description: AI-powered code editor that helps developers write, edit, and understand code faster

limitations.title: Requires Developer Skills
limitations.description: Cursor accelerates developers but doesn't replace them. Non-technical users will struggle to direct the AI effectively or evaluate its output.

limitations.title: Context Window Limits
limitations.description: Large codebases exceed Cursor's context window. The AI may miss important dependencies or produce inconsistent code across large projects.

limitations.title: Hallucinations and Errors
limitations.description: Cursor can confidently generate incorrect code, invent APIs that don't exist, or misunderstand requirements. Developer review is essential.

limitations.title: Subscription Costs Add Up
limitations.description: The Pro tier is needed for serious use, and premium models cost extra. Power users can easily spend $50-100/month.

bestFor: Accelerating experienced developers, code refactoring, understanding unfamiliar codebases
notFor: Non-developers trying to build apps, replacing developer judgment
productionPath: Use Cursor to accelerate development while maintaining code review, testing, and architectural decisions with human oversight
commonProblems: Context gets confused in large projects
Generated tests don't cover edge cases
Still need developer to review everything

faqs.question: Can I use Cursor without knowing how to code?
faqs.answer: Not effectively. Cursor is a developer tool that accelerates coding, not a replacement for coding skills. You need to understand code to direct the AI and evaluate its output.

faqs.question: Is Cursor better than Lovable for building apps?
faqs.answer: They're different tools. Lovable generates complete apps from prompts (but not production-ready). Cursor helps developers write code faster. Developers often use Cursor to finish or fix Lovable projects.

faqs.question: Why does Cursor keep making mistakes?
faqs.answer: AI code generation isn't perfect. Cursor can misunderstand context, invent non-existent APIs, or produce subtle bugs. Always review AI-generated code carefully before using it.

name: Replit
description: Cloud development environment with AI agent that can build and deploy applications

limitations.title: Performance Limitations
limitations.description: Free tier has CPU and memory limits. Production apps can be slow or hit resource caps during traffic spikes.

limitations.title: Vendor Lock-in Concerns
limitations.description: Projects are deeply integrated with Replit's infrastructure. Migrating to standard hosting requires significant work.

limitations.title: Not Enterprise-Ready
limitations.description: Limited security controls, compliance features, and custom domain options compared to professional hosting solutions.

limitations.title: Agent Inconsistency
limitations.description: Replit Agent can produce working code or completely miss the mark. Results vary significantly between projects and prompts.

notFor: Production applications, enterprise software, high-traffic sites
productionPath: Export code, migrate to standard hosting (Vercel, AWS, etc.), refactor for performance, implement proper DevOps

faqs.question: Can I run a production business on Replit?
faqs.answer: Not recommended. Replit is great for prototypes but lacks the performance, security, and reliability needed for production businesses. Plan to migrate to professional hosting.

faqs.question: Why is my Replit app so slow?
faqs.answer: Free tier has limited CPU and memory. Apps 'sleep' after inactivity and take time to 'wake up.' Paid plans help but still have limits compared to dedicated hosting.

name: Claude Artifacts
description: Claude's built-in feature that generates interactive code artifacts including React components and HTML

limitations.title: No Deployment or Hosting
limitations.description: Artifacts are preview-only. There's no built-in way to deploy, host, or share them as real applications.

limitations.title: No Persistence or Backend
limitations.description: Artifacts can't connect to databases, APIs, or save data. Everything resets when you close the chat.

limitations.title: Limited to Single Files
limitations.description: Complex multi-file applications aren't possible. Artifacts work best for single components or simple apps.

limitations.title: Copy-Paste Workflow
limitations.description: To use artifacts in a real project, you must manually copy code into your development environment and handle all integration.

bestFor: Quick component prototyping, code snippets, visual demonstrations
notFor: Full applications, production code, anything requiring persistence
productionPath: Copy artifact code into a proper development environment, add backend, database, authentication, and deployment

faqs.question: Can I deploy a Claude Artifact as a real website?
faqs.answer: Not directly. Artifacts are previews only. You need to copy the code into a development environment, set up hosting, and deploy manually.

faqs.question: Is Claude Artifacts better than Lovable?
faqs.answer: Different tools. Claude Artifacts generates excellent code but has no deployment. Lovable deploys apps but with less sophisticated code. Many users prototype in Claude, then move to other tools.

name: Windsurf
description: AI-powered IDE from Codeium focused on agentic coding workflows

limitations.title: Newer Tool, Less Mature
limitations.description: Windsurf is newer than Cursor with less community support, fewer tutorials, and more rough edges.

limitations.title: Requires Developer Skills
limitations.description: Like Cursor, Windsurf accelerates developers but can't replace fundamental coding knowledge.

limitations.title: Context Limitations
limitations.description: Large codebases can exceed context windows, leading to inconsistent suggestions.

bestFor: Developers wanting an alternative to Cursor, teams exploring AI coding tools
productionPath: Use Windsurf to accelerate development while maintaining human code review and testing
commonProblems: Newer tool with less community support
Requires developer skills to use effectively

faqs.question: Is Windsurf better than Cursor?
faqs.answer: They're comparable. Windsurf has a more generous free tier and focuses on agentic workflows. Cursor has more polish and community. Try both to see which fits your workflow.

name: GitHub Copilot
description: AI pair programmer from GitHub/Microsoft that suggests code as you type

limitations.title: Autocomplete, Not Application Building
limitations.description: Copilot suggests code line-by-line. It doesn't build applications or understand high-level architecture.

limitations.title: Requires Strong Developer Skills
limitations.description: Copilot accelerates coding but requires you to know what you're building. It can't replace architectural decisions or debugging skills.

limitations.title: Can Suggest Insecure or Buggy Code
limitations.description: Copilot's suggestions may contain security vulnerabilities, bugs, or outdated patterns. All suggestions need review.

limitations.title: License and IP Concerns
limitations.description: Copilot trained on public code, raising questions about code licensing and intellectual property.

bestFor: Professional developers wanting faster coding, boilerplate reduction
notFor: Building applications from scratch without coding skills
productionPath: Use Copilot as an assistant while maintaining code review, security scanning, and human architectural decisions

faqs.question: Can GitHub Copilot build me an app?
faqs.answer: No. Copilot is an autocomplete tool that suggests code as you type. It doesn't understand what you're building or generate complete applications. You still need to architect and write the application.

faqs.question: Is Copilot worth $10/month?
faqs.answer: For professional developers, usually yes. Studies show 30-50% productivity gains. For beginners or non-developers, the value is much lower since you need coding skills to use it effectively.

name: Firebase Studio
description: Google's AI-powered cloud development environment with Firebase integration

limitations.title: Newer Platform, Still Evolving
limitations.description: Firebase Studio is relatively new with features still being added. Documentation and community support are growing but limited.

limitations.title: Google Ecosystem Lock-in
limitations.description: Deep Firebase integration is great if you're committed to Google, but makes migrating to other platforms harder.

limitations.title: Requires Understanding of Firebase
limitations.description: The AI helps but you still need to understand Firebase concepts like Firestore, Auth, and Cloud Functions.

bestFor: Developers building Firebase-based applications, Google Cloud users
notFor: Projects needing platform flexibility, AWS/Azure shops
productionPath: Build in Firebase Studio, deploy to Firebase/Google Cloud, understand you're committed to the Google ecosystem

faqs.question: Is Firebase Studio good for beginners?
faqs.answer: Somewhat. It lowers barriers but you still need to understand Firebase concepts. The AI helps but can't replace learning how Firebase works.

name: Create.xyz
description: AI development platform that generates full-stack applications from prompts

limitations.title: Similar Limitations to Other Builders
limitations.description: Like Lovable and Bolt, Create.xyz generates prototypes well but struggles with production-ready complex applications.

limitations.title: Less Community and Documentation
limitations.description: Smaller user base means fewer tutorials, examples, and community support compared to Lovable or Bolt.

bestFor: Quick prototypes, exploring AI app building
productionPath: Export code, refactor for production, add proper architecture and security
commonProblems: Similar limitations to other AI builders

faqs.question: How does Create.xyz compare to Lovable?
faqs.answer: Similar capabilities with different interfaces. Both generate React apps from prompts, both have limitations for production use. Try both to see which workflow you prefer.

name: Bubble
description: Visual no-code platform for building web applications without writing code

limitations.title: Performance Issues at Scale
limitations.description: Bubble apps often become slow as they grow. Complex apps can have significant loading times and performance issues.

limitations.title: Vendor Lock-in
limitations.description: Bubble apps can't be exported. You're locked to their platform forever. If Bubble goes down or raises prices, you have no exit strategy.

limitations.title: Limited Customization
limitations.description: You can only do what Bubble allows. Custom features often require workarounds or expensive plugins.

limitations.title: Expensive at Scale
limitations.description: Enterprise pricing gets expensive quickly. High-traffic apps can cost $500-2,000/month or more.

bestFor: Non-technical founders validating ideas, internal tools, simple web apps
notFor: High-performance apps, enterprise software, mobile apps
productionPath: Validate with Bubble, then rebuild in code for production if successful
commonProblems: Apps get slow as they grow
No code export or migration path

faqs.question: Can I export my Bubble app?
faqs.answer: No. Bubble is a proprietary platform with no code export. Your app only runs on Bubble's servers. If you outgrow the platform, you'd need to rebuild from scratch in code.

faqs.question: Is Bubble good for startups?
faqs.answer: For early validation, yes. For scaling a successful product, often no. Many startups use Bubble for MVP then rebuild in code once they have traction and funding.

name: Webflow
description: Visual website builder that generates clean code without requiring programming skills

limitations.title: Websites, Not Web Apps
limitations.description: Webflow builds websites, not applications. Complex user interactions, dashboards, and dynamic functionality require significant workarounds.

limitations.title: Steep Learning Curve
limitations.description: Webflow's power comes with complexity. It takes weeks or months to become proficient, and the interface can be overwhelming.

limitations.title: Limited Backend Capabilities
limitations.description: Webflow's CMS is basic. Complex data relationships, user authentication, and business logic require external services.

limitations.title: Expensive for Teams
limitations.description: Workspace plans for collaboration and client billing get expensive quickly, especially for agencies.

bestFor: Marketing sites, portfolios, blogs, landing pages
notFor: Web applications, complex user auth, dashboards
productionPath: Use Webflow for marketing site, integrate with separate app for functionality

faqs.question: Can I build an app in Webflow?
faqs.answer: Not really. Webflow is designed for websites, not applications. You can add some interactivity, but user authentication, databases, and complex functionality require external tools like Memberstack or custom code.

faqs.question: Is Webflow better than coding?
faqs.answer: For certain use cases, yes. If you need a marketing site or portfolio and aren't a developer, Webflow can be faster than learning to code. But for web applications, coding gives you more flexibility.

name: Framer
description: Design and publish websites with advanced animations and interactions

limitations.title: Limited to Static Sites
limitations.description: Framer excels at marketing sites but can't build web applications with user auth, databases, or complex logic.

limitations.title: CMS Limitations
limitations.description: Framer's CMS is basic and limited compared to dedicated CMS platforms or Webflow.

limitations.title: Can't Export Code Easily
limitations.description: While Framer uses React, exporting clean, maintainable code isn't straightforward.

limitations.title: Performance with Heavy Animations
limitations.description: Complex animations can impact page performance and loading times.

bestFor: Marketing sites, landing pages, portfolios with rich animations
productionPath: Use Framer for marketing site, separate solution for application functionality

faqs.question: Is Framer better than Webflow?
faqs.answer: For certain use cases. Framer is easier to learn, has better animations, and is cheaper. Webflow has a more powerful CMS and more mature ecosystem. Choose based on your specific needs.

faqs.question: Can I use Framer for a web app?
faqs.answer: No. Framer is for websites, not applications. It doesn't support user authentication, databases, or complex backend logic. Use a dedicated app builder for that.

name: Glide
description: Build mobile and web apps from Google Sheets or Airtable without coding

limitations.title: Limited by Spreadsheet Architecture
limitations.description: Using Google Sheets as a database works for simple apps but breaks down with complex data relationships or scale.

limitations.title: Limited Customization
limitations.description: Glide's templates and components are limiting. Custom designs and features require workarounds.

limitations.title: Not for Production Apps
limitations.description: Glide is great for prototypes and internal tools but not robust enough for customer-facing production apps.

limitations.title: Performance with Large Datasets
limitations.description: Apps slow down significantly as Google Sheets grows beyond a few thousand rows.

bestFor: Internal tools, simple mobile apps, prototypes
notFor: Customer-facing apps, complex data, high-scale applications
productionPath: Prototype in Glide, rebuild in code or proper no-code platform for production

faqs.question: Can Glide handle thousands of users?
faqs.answer: Not well. Glide uses Google Sheets as a database, which isn't designed for concurrent users. Beyond a few hundred users or a few thousand rows, performance degrades significantly.

faqs.question: Is Glide good for a startup MVP?
faqs.answer: For very simple apps, yes. For anything with complex data or expecting real users, you'll quickly hit limits. Consider it for internal tools or very early prototyping only.

name: Softr
description: Build web apps and portals from Airtable or Google Sheets with pre-built blocks

limitations.title: Limited by Airtable/Sheets Architecture
limitations.description: Like Glide, using Airtable as a database works for simple apps but limits complex applications.

limitations.title: Design Constraints
limitations.description: Softr's block-based approach limits design flexibility. Custom layouts are difficult.

limitations.title: Expensive for Features
limitations.description: Essential features like custom domains and user management require higher-tier paid plans.

limitations.title: Limited Interactivity
limitations.description: Complex workflows, multi-step forms, and conditional logic are limited.

bestFor: Client portals, directories, member sites, internal tools
notFor: Complex applications, custom designs, high-scale products
productionPath: Use Softr for simple portals, move to custom development for complex needs

faqs.question: Is Softr better than Bubble?
faqs.answer: Different tools for different needs. Softr is easier and faster for simple portals. Bubble is more powerful but complex. Choose Softr for quick, simple apps; Bubble for more complex logic.

faqs.question: Can I build a marketplace with Softr?
faqs.answer: Simple ones, yes. Complex marketplaces with payments, messaging, and complex matching would be very limited. Consider purpose-built marketplace tools or custom development instead.

name: Retool
description: Build internal tools quickly by connecting to databases and APIs with a visual interface

limitations.title: Internal Tools Only
limitations.description: Retool is designed for internal tools, not customer-facing applications. The UI and performance aren't suited for external users.

limitations.title: Per-User Pricing Gets Expensive
limitations.description: At $10-50/user/month, costs add up quickly for larger teams. Enterprise pricing is even higher.

limitations.title: Requires Technical Knowledge
limitations.description: While no-code for simple tools, complex integrations require SQL and JavaScript knowledge.

limitations.title: Limited Design Flexibility
limitations.description: Retool's component library is functional but not beautiful. Custom styling is limited.

bestFor: Admin panels, internal dashboards, ops tools for technical teams
notFor: Customer-facing apps, marketing sites, non-technical users
productionPath: Use Retool for internal tools, custom development for customer-facing products

faqs.question: Can I use Retool for my SaaS?
faqs.answer: Only for internal admin tools. Retool isn't designed for customer-facing applications. The performance, design, and pricing model aren't suited for external users.

faqs.question: Is Retool worth the cost?
faqs.answer: For technical teams building internal tools, often yes. A tool that would take weeks to code can be built in hours. For non-technical teams or small internal tools, simpler alternatives may be more cost-effective.

name: GPT Engineer
description: Open-source AI tool that generates entire codebases from natural language specifications

limitations.title: Inconsistent Output Quality
limitations.description: Generated code quality varies significantly. Complex projects often have bugs, missing features, or poor architecture.

limitations.title: Requires Developer to Review and Fix
limitations.description: The generated code needs significant review and often substantial fixes. It's a starting point, not a finished product.

limitations.title: API Costs Add Up
limitations.description: Using GPT-4 API for code generation is expensive. Complex projects can cost $50-200 in API calls.

limitations.title: Limited Context Understanding
limitations.description: GPT Engineer struggles with large codebases and complex requirements. Context window limitations affect quality.

bestFor: Developers wanting a starting point, exploring AI code generation
notFor: Non-developers, production code without review, complex applications
productionPath: Use as a starting point, then significantly refactor, review, and test before production
commonProblems: Needs developer to fix and refactor

faqs.question: Can GPT Engineer build a complete app?
faqs.answer: It can generate a starting point, but expect to spend significant time debugging and refactoring. It's not a finished product generator - more like an advanced boilerplate creator.

faqs.question: Is GPT Engineer better than Copilot?
faqs.answer: Different tools. GPT Engineer generates entire codebases from specs. Copilot suggests code as you type. GPT Engineer for project scaffolding, Copilot for ongoing development.
